overview:
Camilo is founder and CEO of PayByGroup, a group payment platform so no single person is on the hook for group purchases like vacation rentals, concerts, sporting events, etc. PayByGroup integrates directly with merchants and employs a Kickstarter model where payments only go through once a minimum number of people have bought in. PayByGroup is a 500 Startups company, and Camilo’s second venture with Frank Langston.

Before starting PayByGroup, Camilo and Frank started Root Orange, a domain-splitting business that allowed a different business in every city to use the exact same domain name at the same time.

Prior to that, Camilo worked for his momâ€™s government communications company,The Media Network, where he introduced newfangled tools young people use like Facebook and Twitter to the companyâ€™s communications offerings. Years later, the federal government is still figuring out how to use social media. He also oversaw the companyâ€™s website re-design, which introduced him to the headache of website re-design. Camiloâ€™s previous gigs include stints at the Corporate Executive Board and New Vantage Group, a venture capital firm in Northern Virginia.

During the rare times he is not working, Camilo does fundraising and advocacy work for education reform efforts, a cause both he and Frank fervently support. He was almost assaulted once by an angry mob of fired (read: low-performing) public school teachers while testifying at a D.C. City Council hearing. Camilo enjoyed the experience and The Washington Post found it newsworthy.

Camilo received his B.A. in Politics from Princeton University, where his thesis on micro-finance in South Africa inexplicably managed to receive the Picard Prize. He is a graduate of the Sidwell Friends School in Washington, D.C, where he enjoyed pasta dinners with Al Gore at the Vice Presidentâ€™s residence and seeing Hillary Clinton in frumpy mom clothes.
